messages: 5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:05): net neutrality: for or against?
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:05): for
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:05): you realize the can of worms it opens up?
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:06): well
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:06): we've had net neutrality all along
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:06): and that the whole thing is the story of the little boy who cried 'wolf'?
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:06): take away net neutality and we go back to BBSes
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:07): Bah. One guy made some stupid remarks. The blogger community cried and cried, and now the congresscritters are involved
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:07): When if it had been left alone, SBC might even have tried their 'toll lane', found out it would not work, and given up on the idea
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:08): mark my words - if this gets rolling, it'll become like telco regulation currently
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:08): ISP's will have to get legislative approval to *lower* their rates
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:09): well
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:10): true
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:10): I've read most of wat the savetheinternet.com bozos wrote, and some other treatises on this, and these guys don't understand networks OR free markets
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:10): *saod
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:11): I am reminded of the 'internet tax' scare of the late 80's, early 90's
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:11): blah
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:11): yeah. It's time to start fighting back against these lame-ass soundbites
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:11): how hard can it be to find a windows zeroconf capable web server???
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:11): yeah
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:12): I didn't actually get ticked about this till I saw last weeks NOW (a news show on PBS), and ohmigod, it is full of crap.
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:12): uhm, OS's do zeroconf. web servers run on top of OS's?
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:13): quux: well i need an implimentation that will run on windows
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:13): apache based would be nice, but i don't mind running yet another web server
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:13): I don;t understand how web server and zeroconf go together?
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:14): quux: ever used SUSE KDE?
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:14): there's a small web server in it
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:14): ok ..
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:14): basically its faster than apache on my lan, and very easy to use
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:14): i want to get one on windows cause my fileserver is on it
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:14): but zeroconf is SUSE's problem, not the web servers
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:15): and combine it with a VPN
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:15): nope
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:15): oddly
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:15): there's a java zeroconf implimentation that would work on windows
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:16): er
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:16): kinda like a lib i guess
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:16): IANAP ;p
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:16): wait. So this is a web server that assigns itself an IP ?
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:16): yup, on a lan
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:16): and broadcasts itself
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:16): again - why? The OS already has an IP?
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:17): so that a suitable client (i use IE+an apple plugin) can see it
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:17): well
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:17): you don't need to know the IP
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:17): and the KDE implimentation is VERY fast
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:17): well
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:17): It's funny. People cuss at netbios
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:17): mostly acedemic interest TBH ;p
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:17): but I see this zeroconf thing as a re-invented netbios
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:18): could be, could be
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:18): ;p
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:18): and bonjour to you, Mr. Jobs!
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:18): i don;t want to get a second suse system to try it too
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:19): i could, but a full suse+KDE feels rather impractical for now
c3a1fa1c49c083817f4c74878181d845 (14:19): quux: it's more like reinvented appletalk
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:19): if i knew java...
c3a1fa1c49c083817f4c74878181d845 (14:19): only less chatty ;)
c3a1fa1c49c083817f4c74878181d845 (14:19): oh and no zones
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:19): when you start having services announce themselves ...
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:20): and you have a big flat network ...
c3a1fa1c49c083817f4c74878181d845 (14:20): appletalk did that :)
c3a1fa1c49c083817f4c74878181d845 (14:20): worse than netbios :)
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:20): this is why MS ditched netbios
c3a1fa1c49c083817f4c74878181d845 (14:20): apple ditched appletalk, too
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:20): that kind of 'floating nameserver' and 'arbitrate by broadcast election' stuff just don't scale
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:21): and when it breaks, oooh, the pain
c3a1fa1c49c083817f4c74878181d845 (14:21): there is no arbitration with rendezvous
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:21): so: how is an IP and netmask chosen?
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:22): quux: http://www.zeroconf.org/
5c25b7bfc49ce3ff8821c0ec86afa4b7 (14:22): how do services differentiate themselves so they can be referred to individually?
c3a1fa1c49c083817f4c74878181d845 (14:22): the ip range and netmask is static, iirc
c3a1fa1c49c083817f4c74878181d845 (14:22): and i imagine arp for choosing the ip
c3a1fa1c49c083817f4c74878181d845 (14:23): ARPing seems as reliable as anything for grabbing an ip from an unknown pool of a /8
